title: Free Water Deficit in Hypernatremia
description: Calculates free water deficit by estimated total body water in patients with hypernatremia or dehydration

parameters.name: sex
parameters.description: Patient sex (affects total body water percentage)

parameters.name: age_category
parameters.description: Patient age category (affects total body water percentage)

result.name: free_water_deficit
result.description: Free water deficit in liters to correct hypernatremia

ranges.interpretation: Small free water deficit. Consider oral hydration if patient can tolerate. Monitor serum sodium closely.
Moderate free water deficit. Consider IV fluid replacement with 5% dextrose or hypotonic saline. Correct slowly over 48 hours.
Severe free water deficit. Requires careful IV fluid management. Correct no faster than 0.5 mEq/L per hour to avoid cerebral edema.
Critical free water deficit. Requires intensive monitoring and gradual correction. Consider ICU management and nephrology consultation.

references: Adrogue HJ, Madias NE. Hypernatremia. N Engl J Med. 2000;342(20):1493-9. doi: 10.1056/NEJM200005183422006.
Moritz ML, Ayus JC. The changing pattern of hypernatremia in hospitalized children. Pediatrics. 1999;104(3 Pt 1):435-9. doi: 10.1542/peds.104.3.435.

Verbalis JG, Goldsmith SR, Greenberg A, et al. Diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of hyponatremia: expert panel recommendations. Am J Med. 2013;126(10 Suppl 1):S1-42. doi: 10.1016/j.amjmed.2013.07.006.
formula: Free water deficit (L) = Total body water fraction × Weight (kg) × (Current Na/Desired Na - 1)
notes: Total body water fractions: Adult male 0.6, Adult female 0.5, Elderly male 0.5, Elderly female 0.45, Child 0.6
Correction should not exceed 0.5 mEq/L per hour to prevent cerebral edema
Target correction of 10 mEq/L in first 24 hours, then 10 mEq/L per day until normal
Add additional fluid for ongoing losses (insensible, urine, etc.)
Monitor serum sodium every 12 hours during correction
May be inaccurate in patients with significant weight changes
Should only be used when patient is hypernatremic but not volume depleted
Consider nephrology consultation for severe hypernatremia or complex cases
